intro: Thellungia advena, commonly known as the creeping bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It features a mat-forming growth habit with fleshy, blue-green leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to violet, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its root system is fibrous and adapted to dry, rocky soils, allowing it to thrive in arid environments. Thellungia advena is often found in open habitats such as grasslands, slopes, and disturbed areas.
